title: 110_s2476
content: The "Improved Vaccine Supply Act" is cited as the short title. It amends the Public Health Service Act to include a new section on adequate vaccine supply. The Secretary will develop a plan for purchasing and storing a supply of vaccines for children and adults to cover recommended vaccinations for a 6-month period. The Secretary will purchase and store vaccines for children and adults as recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, including those designated for public health preparedness efforts. The Secretary will purchase and store vaccines recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, including those designated for public health preparedness efforts, using specific authorities outlined in the Social Security Act and other relevant legislation. The Secretary will submit a plan developed under subsection (a) to specific Senate and House committees within 6 months of the enactment of this section. The Secretary will submit a plan to Senate and House committees regarding the basis, prioritization, and implementation of vaccine purchasing by September 30, 2008. The Secretary must implement the plan for vaccine purchasing by 2008. Manufacturers must give at least 1 year notice to the Secretary before discontinuing vaccine production. The manufacturer must provide at least 1 year notice to the Secretary before discontinuing vaccine production, unless good cause exists for reduction. Proceeds from vaccine sales are available to the Secretary for the purpose of maintaining the vaccine supply. The sale of vaccines from the supply can be used by the Secretary to purchase more vaccines. Ongoing reports detailing progress and any impediments must be submitted periodically. The Secretary must submit reports on the progress and impediments in implementing the plan, along with a recommendation on extending the vaccine supply beyond 6 months and the reasons behind it. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 is provided to carry out the section, including discussions on recommendations and considerations.
